Downtime Mode

Systems and mechanics for rest, recovery, and long-term activities

When characters are spending days, weeks, or months between adventures, you're in Downtime Mode. This mode handles rest, recovery, training, crafting, and other activities that take significant time.

Core Systems for Downtime

Resting

The primary recovery system:

  • Short Rest (1 hour):
    • Spend Hit Dice to regain HP
    • Recover some class features
  • Long Rest (8 hours):
    • Regain all lost HP
    • Regain up to half your total Hit Dice
    • Regain all spell slots
    • Reduce Exhaustion by 1 level

Exhaustion

Recovering from fatigue:

  • Each Long Rest reduces Exhaustion by 1 level
  • Comfortable rest and adequate food speeds recovery

Equipment & Items

Crafting and shopping:

  • Crafting Items: Progress at 5 gp value per day of work
  • Buying Equipment: Availability depends on settlement size
  • Selling Treasure: Typically 50% of item value

Downtime Activities

Crafting (Varies)

  • Progress: 5 gp per day of work
  • Requirements: Tools, materials (half item cost), workspace

Practicing a Profession (1+ days)

  • Ability Check: Related skill
  • Earnings: Based on check result

Recuperating (3+ days)

  • Benefit: Advantage on saves to recover from disease or poison

Researching (Varies)

  • Cost: 1 gp per day
  • Examples: Ancient history, monster lore, spell research

Training (250+ days)

  • Cost: 1 gp per day (teacher or materials)
  • Gain: One language or tool proficiency

Lifestyle Expenses

LifestyleCost/Day
Squalid1 sp
Poor2 sp
Modest1 gp
Comfortable2 gp
Wealthy4 gp
Aristocratic10+ gp

Transitioning Out of Downtime Mode

Downtime mode typically transitions to:

  • Interaction Mode: When meeting patrons or receiving new quests
  • Exploration Mode: When beginning a new adventure
  • Travel Mode: When leaving town for a distant location
